title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress acknowledges the historical significance of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., as a symbol of democracy and the challenges it faces in accommodating its 5,000,000 annual visitors. Recognizing the vital role of the United States Capitol Police in ensuring security, Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for the construction of a Capitol Visitor Center to enhance visitor experience and maintain high security standards. Congress aims to enhance the educational experience for Capitol visitors by allowing voluntary fundraising for the Capitol Visitor Center. Proceeds from the sale of commemorative coins will support the construction, maintenance, and preservation of the center. The text chunk "SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS." is a concise statement regarding the specifications of the commemorative coins that will be sold to support the construction, maintenance, and preservation of the Capitol Visitor Center. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions as outlined in the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may mint $5 gold coins if bimetallic coins are not feasible, with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The minting levels specified in the Act can be waived, and the coins minted will be legal tender. SEC. 4. The Secretary will obtain platinum, gold, and silver from available sources for minting coins under this Act. SEC. 5. The design of coins will be determined accordingly. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building, featuring inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins under this Act will feature a design symbolizing the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various committees. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint used for each denomination and quality combination. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission for promotion and marketing, potentially entering into a contract for these purposes. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Commission or an entity to carry out a specific role established under the Act. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge. The Secretary will establish surcharges for coins sold under this Act, ranging from $3 to $50 per coin depending on the denomination. The surcharges received from the sale of coins minted under this Act will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund to aid in the construction, maintenance, and preservation of a Capitol Visitor Center.
